entry.title: Sequential Monte Carlo
entry.content:
Introduction

Lots of real-world data analysis efforts often include estimating the unknown data from a limited number of given observations. From a Bayesian perspective, one must use a prior distribution of the unobservable quantity of interest and likelihood functions which relate the observables to the unobservables to model the time series data. Generally, the observations are recorded in chronological order, which helps to inference the unknown data and continuously update the posterior distribution. Such Bayesian models are often taken advantage in many areas including estimating digital signals and analyze the volatility of stock market.

Sequential Monte Carlo (SMC) methods are simulation-based methods for calculating approximations to posterior distributions. They avoid making linearity or normality assumptions required by related methods such as the Kalman filter. Obviously, it is too sophisticated for approaches based on deterministic numerical integration to yield the accurate results. In practical cases, data often shows in high dimensions (e.g., human motion skeleton analysis), which makes those methods even more difficult to calculate. Sequential Monte Carlo, on the other hand, is a simulation-based method that provides a convenient way to compute the posterior distribution without necessarily computing an explicit result.

Model

Let ${xt}{t=0}^\infty$ denote the sequence of unobserved states, with $xt\inğ’³$. We consider only the case when ${x_t}$ is a Markov process with initial distribution $p(x0)$, which actually is not necessary and is only for tractability. Let $p(x_t|x{tâˆ’1})$ denote the transition equation. Let ${yt}{t=1}^\infty$ denote a sequence of observations with $yt\inğ’´$. Suppose that, given ${x_t}$, the observations are conditionally independent. Let $p(y_t|y{tâˆ’1})$ denote the marginal distribution, or the observation equation.

In brief, we use $x$ to describe the states and $y$ to describe the observations. Our goal is to estimate the posterior distribution and its corresponding characteristics (mean, variance, covariance, etc.) in time series.

At any time $t$, the posterior distribution is given by Bayesâ€™ theorem

It is possible to obtain straightforwardly a recursive formula for this joint distribution ${\displaystyle p}{\displaystyle(}{\displaystyle x{0:t}}{\displaystyle\vert}{\displaystyle y{1:t}}{)}$,

The marginal distribution ${\displaystyle p}{\displaystyle(}{\displaystyle x{t}}{\displaystyle\vert}{\displaystyle y{1:t-1}}{)}$ also satisfies the following recursion.

Such constants and posteriors, however, involve high-dimensional integrals, which are definitely not easy to solve. In SMC, one can approximate the distribution for sampling estimation, such as importance sampling, sequential importance sampling, etc.

Monte Carlo Sampling

Monte Carlo sampling of a probability distribution $p(x)$ is divided into three main types: direct sampling, rejection sampling and importance sampling.

For a probability distribution with a known probability density function and a cumulative probability density function, one can sample directly from the cumulative distribution function (cdf), and this is what we called as direct sampling. For distributions with unknown cumulative distribution functions, we can use rejection sampling. As shown in the figure below, $p(z)$ is the distribution we want to sample, $q(z)$ is our proposed distribution, so that $kq(z) > p(z)$. We first sample the particles in $kq(z)$ according to the direct sampling method, and then judge what region the particles fall in on the way, for the particles falling in the gray area to be rejected, and the particles falling under the The particles that fall under the red line are accepted, and finally we get $N$ particles that conform to $p(z)$.

Sequential Importance Sampling and Particle Filter

Both direct sampling and rejection sampling assume equal weights for each particle, while importance sampling gives each particle a different weight and uses a weighted average method to calculate the expectation.

For the state space model, sequential importance sampling is widely considered empirically useful and effective. One first samples the variables at moment $t$ from the proposed distribution, and next calculates the sequence weights by multiplying the particle weights of the previous generation with the particle weights calculated in the current.

Sequence importance sampling can solve the particle weights corresponding to an entire time series, but such sampling may result in small weights for some particle sequences and large weights for only a few particle sequences. In the long run, the expectation and area calculated by this method might be unstable.

Resampling is used to solve such problems. We copy the particle sequences with larger weights and discard the particle sequences with smaller weights. After that, we obtain $N$ sequences of particles with equal weights. By resampling, we can avoid the problem that some particles have small weights and some have large weights due to too many iterations of weights in importance sampling. The main resampling methods include systematic resampling, residual resampling, polynomial resampling, etc. The following figure shows how resampling works.

entry.content:

Linear Models

Linear regression is one of the most common approaches used for prediction. It is a type of linear model that is considered the most basic used predictive algorithm. This can not be dissociated from its simple, yet effective architecture. A linear model assumes a linear relationship between input variable(s) ğ‘¥ and an output variable y. The equation for a linear model can be written in vector form like this:

where

In the equation 1, we show a linear model with several features. w is considered the weights assigned to each feature. The goal for such a linear model is to optimize the weight(b) via the cost function:

Regularization

In practical stages, we may encounter overfitting and underfitting during the training process. Overfitting means the model learns too much information and performs almost perfect in training data, but not so well in test data. Underfitting, however, is another case. It happens when model neither performs well on the train set nor on the test set due to lacking training iterations.

Regularization is implemented to avoid overfitting. When there is a huge variance between train and test set performances, the number of features used in training has to be kept constant and the magnitude of weights should reduce.

Ridge Regression

Letâ€™s start by collecting Weight and Size measurements from a bunch of mice. Generally, we can fit such a line to the data using Least Squares.

But when it comes a situation that we only have two data points, the usual Linear Regression approach will just find a line that overlaps the two data points.

Obviously, such a result performs not so well as before, if we add the rest of the points. That means the new line has high variance. In machine learning lingo, weâ€™d say that this new model is overfitting to the training data.

Thus, Ridge Regression is implemented to solve such issues. The main idea behind Ridge Regression is to find a new line that doesnâ€™t fit the training data so well, but with a small amount of bias introduced.

In Ridge Regression, we modify the cost function of Linear Regression to this:

So the main difference between the old cost function and the new one is, we introduce the penalty as Î» Ã— slopeÂ². When the sample size are relatively small, Ridge Regression can improve predictions made from new data by making the predictions less sensitive to the training data. Ridge regression is also referred to as L2 Regularization.

Lasso Regression

Lasso Regression is a regularization technique used in feature selection using a Shrinkage method also referred to as the penalized regression method, which is similar to Ridge Regression we mentioned before. Lasso is short for Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator, which is used both for regularization and model selection. If a model uses the L1 regularization technique, then it is called lasso regression.

The superficial difference between Lasso Regression and Ridge Regression is the penalty where instead of squaring the slope, we take the absolute value. The cost function of Lasso Regression is:

But the big difference is that Lasso Regression can exclude useless variables from equations. This makes the final equation simpler and easier to interpret. So in many practical cases, Lasso is also implemented to Features Selection problems.

entry.content:
Xv6 is a teaching operating system developed in the summer of 2006 for MITâ€™s operating systems course, 6.828: Operating System Engineering.

For many years, MIT had no operating systems course. In the fall of 2002, one was created to teach operating systems engineering. In the course lectures, the class worked through Sixth Edition Unix (aka V6) using John Lionsâ€™s famous commentary. In the lab assignments, students wrote most of an exokernel operating system, eventually named Jos, for the Intel x86. V6 presented pedagogic challenges from the start. Students doubted the relevance of an obsolete 30-year-old operating system written in an obsolete programming language (pre-K&R C) running on obsolete hardware (the PDP-11).

By the summer of 2006, we had decided to replace V6 with a new operating system, xv6, modeled on V6 but written in ANSI C and running on multiprocessor Intel x86 machines. Xv6â€™s use of the x86 makes it more relevant to studentsâ€™ experience than V6 was and unifies the course around a single architecture. Adding multiprocessor support requires handling concurrency head on with locks and threads (instead of using special-case solutions for uniprocessors such as enabling/disabling interrupts) and helps relevance. Finally, writing a new system allowed us to write cleaner versions of the rougher parts of V6, like the scheduler and file system. 6.828 substituted xv6 for V6 in the fall of 2006.

  1. These large cities needed some form of centralized administration.
  2. Archaeological evidence indicates that the organization initially was provided by religion, for the largest building in each city was a massive temple honoring one of the Mesopotamian gods.
